required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: NIRS for AKI in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Use of NIRS to Detect Acute Kidney Injury in Preterm Infants

brief_summary.textblock: This study will examine the relationship of oxygen levels, using NIRS monitoring, and kidney injury in infants born prematurely. NIRS is a skin sensor which detects the amount of oxygen going to different organs, most often used to monitor the brain and kidney.

primary_outcome.description: Comparison of Renal saturation (Rsat) in patients with AKI to those without AKI.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of renal NIRS values to serum creatinine and urine output
secondary_outcome.description: In patients with AKI, renal NIRS values (Rsat) will be correlated with changes in serum creatinine and urine output.

secondary_outcome.measure: Effect of neonatal medications on renal NIRS values
secondary_outcome.description: Renal saturation values following administration of neonatal medications will be compared to mean renal saturation values for each specific patient.

arm_group.description: These infants will be monitored with NIRS

intervention.description: Application of regional NIRS sensors to brain and kidney sites in the first 48 hours after birth to monitor regional tissue oxygenation for the first 7 days of age.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Preterm infants < 32 weeks
- Admitted to UPH Meriter NICU
- Application of NIRS by 48 hours of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Congential anomaly of the kidney or urinary tract (CAKUT)
